Award.AwardTitle: G8 Initiative: ExArch: Climate Analytics on Distributed Exascale Data Archives

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This NSF award to UCLA funds U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by the G8 Research Councils Initiative on Multilateral Research through the Interdisciplinary Program on Application Software towards Exascale Computing for Global Scale Issues. This is a pilot collaboration among the U.S. National Science Foundation, the Canadian National Sciences and Engineering Research Council (NSERC), the French Agence Nationale de la Recherche (ANR), the German Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG), the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS), the Russian Foundation for Basic Research (RFBR),and the United Kingdom Research Councils (RC-UK), supporting collaborative research projects selected on a competitive basis that are comprised of researchers from at least three of the partner countries.

This international project targets the rapidly growing demands of climate science data management as models increase the precision with which they depict spatial structure and the completeness with which they describe a vast range of physical processes. The ExArch project is principally a framework for the scientific interpretation of multi-model ensembles at the peta-and exa-scale. It applies a strategy, a prototype infrastructure and demonstration usage examples in the context of the imminent CMIP5 archive, which will be the largest of its kind ever assembled in this domain. It will attach the ExArch framework to the CORDEX experiment, pushing beyond CMIP5 in resolution, albeit at regional scale.

This international project involving collaborating researchers in six countries will explore the challenges of developing a software management infrastructure which will scale to the multi-exabyte archives of climate data which are likely to be crucial to major policy decisions by the end of the decade. In the short term, strategies will be evaluated by applying them to existing data archives. The NSF funding to UCLA primarily supports the extension of the information model to earth observational data and the validation of regional climate models with observational data.

Performance_Institution.Name: Regents of the University of California, Los Angeles - JIFRESSE

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. Major goals of the project

 

The multi-national and multi-institutional collaborative ExArch project aims to build a database, to develop software tools, and to take advantage of hardware improvements for evaluating and analyzing climate data from models and observations on the basis of existing and to-be-developed information technology capabilities at the participating institutions. Evaluation and analyses of regional climate models (RCMs), that are data resource demanding due to their high spatial resolutions, are also specifically targeted in this project. The primary task of the Joint Institute for Regional Earth System Science and Engineering (JIFRESSE) team involves building links between ExArch and the Regional Climate Model Evaluation System (RCMES) that is based on the databases and software including a number of global satellite and reanalysis data sets identified specifically for the evaluation of CMIP5 and RCM outputs that are being developed collaboratively by JPL and UCLA. The RCMES will be employed in model evaluation studies to be closely coordinated with the project members and ongoing climate change programs, such as the COordinated Regional Climate Downscaling Experiment (CORDEX).

 

2. Project Outcomes

 

During the course of the project period, the UCLA investigation team has successfully achieved key objectives of the project and proposed deliverables. These activities are related to the Regional Climate Model Evaluation System (RCMES) via further developments and improvements of the evaluation metrics, databases, computational structures and user-support structures. The data files and the evaluation toolkit from the project have been applied to evaluations of climate model data from multiple international projects of coordinated regional climate projections and studies to analyze key climatological phenomena of regional importance including the effects of atmospheric river landfalls on the rainfall and temperatures in the western United States, mid-summer droughts in the Mesoamerica, and the uncertainties in multiple gridded precipitation data inferred from observations. Details of the project outcomes are presented below

 

(2.1) Enhanced Regional Climate Model Evaluation System (RCMES)

 

The Regional Climate Model Evaluation System (RCMES) has been improved in its computational structures, metrics for model evaluation and the links to major external databases. RCMES and related tutorials are distributed to users at free of charge and without any limitations from the web site https://rcmes.jpl.nasa.gov/content/software-support through the Apache open source project.  Users can visit the RCMES database (https://rcmes.jpl.nasa.gov/content/data-rcmes-database), and make calls to its web service API: http://wrm.jpl.nasa.gov/query-api/query.php.

 

(2.2) Enhanced database with the links with major climate data infrastructure

 

The observational data files used for model evaluations in RCMES have been expanded beyond its local data archives via links to major databases developed through community-wide collaborative efforts including the Earth System Grid Federation (ESGF) and obs4MIPs. In addition, RCMES has been linked to a number of additional local databases from various projects such as NLDAS (NASA), MERRA (NASA), APHRODITE (Japan Met. Agency), PRISM (Oregon State University) and nClimDiv (NOAA).

 

(2.3) Application of RCMES in regional climate studies

 

Since the initial involvement in the CORDEX Africa project in 2011, we have been expanding our collaborations with major CORDEX regional experiments for the Arctic, South Asia, East Asia, Southeast Asia, North America, South America, and Central America regions. RCMES has been employed in recent NASA Dynamic Downscaling Project in which multiple NASA centers participated. In addition, we employed RCMES in evaluating CMIP GCMs in simulating precipitation and temperature over the conterminous US, and the diagnostics of uncertainties in analyzing key precipitation characteristics in India and East Asia due to uncertainties in the observational data products. The list of publications supported by the project is included in a separate appendix.

 

(2.4) Outreach and education

 

The investigators participate in climate research programs in academic institutions by providing RCMES and tutorials. The personnel and institutions involved in ongoing outreach, training and educational activities are listed in the accompanying appendix file.
